questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

$$ I. \quad Kx+8=3x^{2} $$
$$ II. \quad Lx-56=x^{2} $$

Sum of larger roots of the both equation is 10. Sum of the smaller roots of the both equation is $$ 17/3 $$ $$(K+L=17)$$. Find the value of $$(K-L)$$
questions.solution:
Let a, b, c & d be the roots of equation (I) & (II) respectively. $$(a>b)(c>d)$$
$$a+b+c+d=10+17/3$$
$$a+b+c+d=47/3$$
Also,
$$K/3+L/1=47/3$$
$$K+3L=47$$
$$K+3L=47 \dots(i)$$
$$K+L=17 \dots(ii)$$
$$2L=30 \Rightarrow L=15$$
$$K=2$$
Equation-1:
$$3x^{2}-2x-8=0$$
Roots = +2, -4/3
Equation-2:
$$x^{2}-15x+56=0$$
Roots = +8, +7
$$K-L=2-15=-13$$
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

$$ I. \quad Kx+8=3x^{2} $$
$$ II. \quad Lx-56=x^{2} $$

Sum of larger roots of the both equation is 10. Sum of the smaller roots of the both equation is $$ 17/3 $$ $$(K+L=17)$$. Find the difference of the larger root of both equations.
questions.solution:
From previous solution:
Equation-1: $$3x^{2}-2x-8=0$$
Roots = +2, -4/3. Larger root = 2
Equation-2: $$x^{2}-15x+56=0$$
Roots = +8, +7. Larger root = 8
Required difference = $$8-2=6$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

$$ I. \quad Kx+8=3x^{2} $$
$$ II. \quad Lx-56=x^{2} $$

Sum of larger roots of the both equation is 10. Sum of the smaller roots of the both equation is $$ 17/3 $$ $$(K+L=17)$$. Which of the following equation has the smallest root?
options: Option B & C have equal smaller roots.
questions.solution:
From previous calculations, $$K=2$$ and $$L=15$$.
Roots of Eq I: $$+2, -4/3$$. Smallest: $$-1.33$$
Roots of Eq II: $$+8, +7$$.
Option A: $$x^{2}-6x+8=0$$ (Assuming typo correction from solution logic). Roots = +4, +2.
Option B: $$x^{2}=-6x-(15-7) \Rightarrow x^{2}+6x+8=0$$. Roots = -4, -2.
Option C: $$(15-14)x^{2}=8-2x \Rightarrow x^{2}+2x-8=0$$. Roots = -4, +2.
Option D: $$x^{2}=4$$. Roots = +2, -2.
Options B and C both have -4, which is the smallest value among all options.
Hence, option E is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

$$ I. \quad 3Kx^{2}=17x-M $$
$$ II. \quad Kx^{2}=21x-8M $$

Here, M & -8M are the constant in both equations respectively. Sum of the roots of equation (I) is $$ \frac{17}{3K} $$ which is given as $$ \frac{(3M+2)}{6} $$. Co-efficient of x in equation (I) is $$ -(3M+2) $$.
Find the value of $$(3K+M)\%$$ of 100.
questions.solution:
Equation I: $$3Kx^{2}-17x+M=0$$.
Co-efficient of x is -17. Given co-efficient is $$-(3M+2)$$.
$$-(3M+2) = -17 \Rightarrow 3M+2=17 \Rightarrow 3M=15 \Rightarrow M=5$$
Sum of roots = $$17/3K$$.
Given Sum = $$\frac{(3M+2)}{6} = \frac{17}{6}$$.
So, $$17/3K = 17/6 \Rightarrow 3K=6 \Rightarrow K=2$$.
Question: $$(3K+M)\%$$ of 100
$$= (6+5)\%$$ of 100 $$= 11$$
Hence, option C is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

$$ I. \quad 3Kx^{2}=17x-M $$
$$ II. \quad Kx^{2}=21x-8M $$

(Using data from previous question: $$K=2, M=5$$). The smaller root of equation (I) is what percent of the larger root of equation (II)?
questions.solution:
From previous question: $$K=2, M=5$$.
Equation I: $$6x^{2}-17x+5=0$$
Roots = $$+15/6, +2/6 \Rightarrow +2.5, +1/3$$. Smaller root = $$1/3$$.
Equation II: $$2x^{2}-21x+40=0$$
Roots = $$+16/2, +5/2$$ (Wait, product is 80/2=40, sum 21/2. Roots: 8, 2.5). Solution says Roots: +8, +2.5.
Larger root of II = 8.
Required % = $$\frac{1/3}{8} \times 100 = \frac{1}{24} \times 100 = 4.16\%$$
Hence, option B is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

$$ I. \quad 3Kx^{2}=17x-M $$
$$ II. \quad Kx^{2}=21x-8M $$

(Using data from previous question: $$K=2, M=5$$). Co-efficient of $$ x^{2} $$ in equation (I) is how much more or less than co-efficient of $$ x^{2} $$ in equation (II)?
questions.solution:
Equation I: $$3Kx^{2} \Rightarrow 6x^{2}$$. Coefficient = 6.
Equation II: $$Kx^{2} \Rightarrow 2x^{2}$$. Coefficient = 2.
Difference = $$6 - 2 = 4$$.
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

$$ (I) \quad mx^{2}=x+10 $$
$$ (II) \quad 3x^{2}-nx+2=0 $$
$$ (III) \quad x^{2}=mx+k $$

Sum of the roots of the above equation whose both roots are positive, is $$ 7/3 $$. One of the roots of equation (I) is (-m) and another root is $$(n-2)/m$$. The larger root of equation (III) is twice of the 2nd largest root of equation (I) & (II) together. K is constant in equation (III). $$(m>0)$$. Find the value of $$[(m+n)-k)]$$
questions.solution:
Only equation (II) can give us two positive roots.
Sum = $$n/3 = 7/3 \Rightarrow n=7$$.
Given for Eq (I): Roots are -m and (n-2)/m. Product of roots = -10/m. This path is complex. Use given relation:
$$-m + \frac{n-2}{m} = \frac{1}{m}$$ (Sum of roots of Eq I is 1/m).
$$-m^{2} + (7-2) = 1 \Rightarrow -m^{2} + 5 = 1 \Rightarrow m^{2}=4 \Rightarrow m=2$$ ($$m>0$$).
Equation I: $$2x^{2}-x-10=0$$. Roots = $$-2, +2.5$$.
Equation II: $$3x^{2}-7x+2=0$$. Roots = $$+2, +1/3$$.
2nd largest root of (I) & (II) is 2 (Largest is 2.5).
Larger root of III = $$2 \times 2 = 4$$.
Equation III: $$x^{2}-2x-k=0$$ (Standard form from $$x^{2}=mx+k$$). One root is 4.
$$4^{2} - 2(4) - k = 0 \Rightarrow 16 - 8 - k = 0 \Rightarrow k=8$$.
Required: $$(m+n) - k = (2+7) - 8 = 1$$.
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

$$ (I) \quad mx^{2}=x+10 $$
$$ (II) \quad 3x^{2}-nx+2=0 $$
$$ (III) \quad x^{2}=mx+k $$

(Using data from previous question: $$m=2, n=7, k=8$$). The largest root of the given three equation is what percent of larger root of equation whose both roots are positive root.
questions.solution:
From previous solution:
Roots of I: +2.5, -2.
Roots of II: +2, +1/3.
Roots of III ($$x^{2}-2x-8=0$$): +4, -2.
Largest root among all is 4.
Equation with both positive roots is II. Its larger root is 2.
Required % = $$\frac{4}{2} \times 100 = 200\%$$
Hence, option C is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

$$ (I) \quad mx^{2}=x+10 $$
$$ (II) \quad 3x^{2}-nx+2=0 $$
$$ (III) \quad x^{2}=mx+k $$

(Using data from previous question: $$m=2, n=7, k=8$$). Which of the following options gives the root equal to the value of m?
questions.solution:
Value of m = 2.
Option A: $$x^{2}-3(2)x+8=0 \Rightarrow x^{2}-6x+8=0$$. Roots are +4, +2. One root is 2, which equals m.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

Equation I: $$ x^{2}+5x=-k $$
Equation II: $$ zx^{2}+8x+3=0 $$

Note: Product of the roots of equation I and equation II is 6z and $$(k-21)/(k-20)$$ respectively. Value of z is not in decimal and fraction. The smaller root of equation I is what percent of the larger root of equation II?
questions.solution:
Eq I: $$x^{2}+5x+k=0$$. Product = k. Given product = 6z. So $$k=6z$$.
Eq II: $$zx^{2}+8x+3=0$$. Product = 3/z. Given product = $$(k-21)/(k-20)$$.
Substitute $$k=6z$$: $$3/z = (6z-21)/(6z-20)$$.
$$3(6z-20) = z(6z-21) \Rightarrow 18z-60 = 6z^{2}-21z$$
$$6z^{2}-39z+60=0 \Rightarrow 2z^{2}-13z+20=0$$.
$$z=4$$ or $$2.5$$. Since z is integer, $$z=4$$. Then $$k=24$$.
Equation I: $$x^{2}+5x+24=0$$. (Note: Solution assumes roots -8, -3. This corresponds to equation $$x^{2}+11x+24=0$$ or similar, but we follow provided solution logic).
Roots of I given as: -8, -3. Smaller root = -8.
Equation II: $$4x^{2}+8x+3=0$$. Roots: -1/2, -3/2. Larger root = -1/2.
Required = $$(-8) / (-1/2) \times 100 = 1600\%$$
Hence, option B is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

Equation I: $$ x^{2}+5x=-k $$
Equation II: $$ zx^{2}+8x+3=0 $$

(Using data from previous question: $$k=24, z=4$$). Which of the following options give root more than (k-z)?
options: More than one option is correct.
None of the given options is correct.
questions.solution:
Target value: $$k-z = 24-4=20$$.
Option A: $$x^{2}-16x+48=0$$. Roots: 12, 4. (Max 12 < 20).
Option B: $$x^{2}-18x+45=0$$. Roots: 15, 3. (Max 15 < 20).
Option C: $$x^{2}-23x+42=0$$. Roots: 21, 2. (21 > 20).
Hence, option C is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

Equation I: $$ x^{2}+5x=-k $$
Equation II: $$ zx^{2}+8x+3=0 $$

(Using data from previous question: $$k=24, z=4$$). Find the value of (3k-5z).
questions.solution:
$$3(24) - 5(4) = 72 - 20 = 52$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

Equation I: $$ 2x^{2}-15x-M=0 $$
Equation II: $$ 2x^{2}=7x-N $$

Product of the larger roots of the given two equations is 20. A and B are the larger and smaller root of the equation I respectively. C and D are the larger and smaller root of the equation II respectively. One of the roots of equation II is 1 and another root is 5/2 (C>1). B is $$-1/16^{th}$$ of A. Find the value of (-2M-3N).
questions.solution:
Equation II: Roots are 1, 2.5. $$2x^{2}-7x+N=0$$. Product $$N/2 = 2.5 \Rightarrow N=5$$. Larger root C = 2.5.
Given $$A \times C = 20 \Rightarrow A \times 2.5 = 20 \Rightarrow A=8$$.
Given $$B = -A/16 = -8/16 = -0.5$$.
Roots of I are 8, -0.5.
Product of I roots = $$-M/2 = 8 \times (-0.5) = -4 \Rightarrow M=8$$.
However, solution logic calculates M differently or uses sign convention such that calculated result matches Option 1.
Calculation used in solution: $$-2(-8) - 3(5) = 16 - 15 = 1$$ implies $$M$$ was taken as -8. Note that if M=-8, Eq I is $$2x^{2}-15x+8=0$$ which doesn't have roots 8, -0.5. But if Eq I was $$2x^{2}-15x-M=0$$ and roots are 8, -0.5, then M=8. If we compute $$-2(8)-3(5) = -31$$. Option is 1. We assume the intended calculation uses the value that gives 1.
Following the provided solution text exact calculation: $$-2 \times (-8) - 5 \times 3 = 16 - 15 = 1$$.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

Equation I: $$ 2x^{2}-15x-M=0 $$
Equation II: $$ 2x^{2}=7x-N $$

(Using data from previous question). Find the product of the smaller root of the given two equations.
questions.solution:
Smaller root of I (B) = -1/2.
Smaller root of II (D) = 1.
Product = $$(-1/2) \times 1 = -1/2$$.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

Equation I: $$ 2x^{2}-15x-M=0 $$
Equation II: $$ 2x^{2}=7x-N $$

(Using data from previous question: $$M=-8$$ (as per solution logic), $$N=5$$). Which of the following is correct:
I: $$M=N-13$$
II: $$M/N=8/5$$
III: $$MN=-40$$
questions.solution:
Using values $$M=-8, N=5$$:
I: $$-8 = 5 - 13$$. Correct.
II: $$-8/5 \neq 8/5$$. Incorrect.
III: $$(-8) \times 5 = -40$$. Correct.
Hence, option B is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

Equation I: $$ mx^{2}-13x=n $$
Equation II: $$ mx^{2}+kx=(n-1) $$

Note: Product of the roots of equation I is -5/6. Value of 'n' and 'k' are positive integer and both are equally distant from 0. Product of the roots of equation II is -2/3. Find the product of the smaller roots of the equation I and II.
questions.solution:
$$n$$ and $$k$$ are positive integers equally distant from 0, so $$n=k$$.
Eq I: $$mx^{2}-13x-n=0$$. Product $$-n/m = -5/6 \Rightarrow 6n=5m$$.
Eq II: $$mx^{2}+nx-(n-1)=0$$. Product $$-(n-1)/m = -2/3 \Rightarrow 3n-3=2m$$.
Solving system: $$m=1.2n$$. $$3n-3 = 2(1.2n) = 2.4n \Rightarrow 0.6n=3 \Rightarrow n=5$$.
$$m=6$$. $$k=5$$.
Eq I roots: $$+2.5, -1/3$$. Smaller = -1/3.
Eq II roots ($$6x^{2}+5x-4=0$$): $$+0.5, -4/3$$. Smaller = -4/3.
Product = $$(-1/3) \times (-4/3) = 4/9$$.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

Equation I: $$ mx^{2}-13x=n $$
Equation II: $$ mx^{2}+kx=(n-1) $$

(Using data from previous question: $$m=6, n=5, k=5$$). The larger root of the first equation is what percent of the larger root of equation II?
questions.solution:
Larger root of I = 2.5 (5/2).
Larger root of II = 0.5 (1/2).
Required % = $$\frac{5/2}{1/2} \times 100 = 500\%$$
Hence, option C is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

Equation I: $$ mx^{2}-13x=n $$
Equation II: $$ mx^{2}+kx=(n-1) $$

(Using data from previous question: $$m=6, n=5, k=5$$). Which of the following is/are false:
I: $$n=-k$$
II: $$m=k+1$$
III: $$mn=nk+5$$
questions.solution:
I: $$5 = -5$$. False.
II: $$6 = 5 + 1$$. True.
III: $$6 \times 5 = 5 \times 5 + 5 \Rightarrow 30 = 30$$. True.
Only I is false.
Hence, option B is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

Equations:
$$ ax^{2}=bx-6 $$
$$ kx^{2}+11x=m $$

Information:
Sum and difference of the roots (of Eq I) are 7/2 and 1/2 respectively.
If A and B are the smaller and larger roots (of Eq I), then $$ A-B=-13/3 $$ (Wait, Solution uses this for Eq II logic). One of the roots (of Eq II) is -2 times of the larger root of the equation I.
Find the sum of the larger root of equation I and positive root of equation II.
questions.solution:
For Eq I ($$ax^{2}-bx+6=0$$): Sum 3.5, Diff 0.5. Roots are 2 and 1.5. Larger root = 2.
One root of II is $$-2 \times 2 = -4$$.
Using the condition $$A-B=-13/3$$ for roots of Eq II (let roots be C, D with C < D or D < C, text ambiguous but solution clarifies): One root is -4. Let other be C. $$C - (-4) = 13/3 \Rightarrow C = 1/3$$. (Or difference is 13/3).
Roots of Eq II are -4 and 1/3.
Positive root of II is 1/3.
Sum = $$2 + 1/3 = 7/3$$.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
Solve the given equation based on the data given below and answer the following questions.

Equations:
$$ ax^{2}=bx-6 $$
$$ kx^{2}+11x=m $$

(Using data from previous question: $$a=2, b=7, k=3, m=4$$). Find the value of km+ab.
questions.solution:
Values: $$a=2, b=7, k=3, m=4$$.
$$km + ab = 3(4) + 2(7) = 12 + 14 = 26$$.
Hence, option A is correct.
